dt: {bc}a sweet crystallizable material that consists wholly or essentially of sucrose, is colorless or white when pure tending to brown when less refined, is obtained commercially from {a_link|sugarcane} or sugar beet and less extensively from sorghum, maples, and palms, and is important as a source of dietary carbohydrate and as a sweetener and preservative of other foods
{bc}any of various water-soluble compounds that vary widely in sweetness, include the monosaccharides and oligosaccharides, and typically are optically active
{bc}a unit (such as a spoonful, cube, or lump) of sugar

et: Middle English {it}sugre, sucre{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}sucre{/it}, from Medieval Latin {it}zuccarum{/it}, from Old Italian {it}zucchero{/it}, from Arabic {it}sukkar{/it}, from Persian {it}shakar{/it}, ultimately from Sanskrit {it}śarkarā{/it}; akin to Sanskrit {it}śarkara{/it} pebble {ma}{mat|crocodile|}{/ma}
shortdef: a sweet crystallizable material that consists wholly or essentially of sucrose, is colorless or white when pure tending to brown when less refined, is obtained commercially from sugarcane or sugar beet and less extensively from sorghum, maples, and palms, and is important as a source of dietary carbohydrate and as a sweetener and preservative of other foods
any of various water-soluble compounds that vary widely in sweetness, include the monosaccharides and oligosaccharides, and typically are optically active
a unit (such as a spoonful, cube, or lump) of sugar

dt: {bc}to form or be converted into sugar
{bc}to make maple syrup or maple sugar

shortdef: to make palatable or attractive : sweeten
to sprinkle or mix with sugar
to form or be converted into sugar

dt: {bc}a tropical American tree ({it}Annona squamosa{/it}) of the custard-apple family
{bc}its edible sweet pulpy fruit with thick green scaly rind and shining black seeds

shortdef: a tropical American tree (Annona squamosa) of the custard-apple family; also : its edible sweet pulpy fruit with thick green scaly rind and shining black seeds

dt: {bc}a white-rooted beet grown for the sugar in its roots

shortdef: a white-rooted beet grown for the sugar in its roots

dt: {bc}a woods in which sugar maples predominate

shortdef: a woods in which sugar maples predominate

dt: {bc}a well-to-do usually older man who supports or spends lavishly on a mistress, girlfriend, or boyfriend
{bc}a generous benefactor of a cause or undertaking

shortdef: a well-to-do usually older man who supports or spends lavishly on a mistress, girlfriend, or boyfriend
a generous benefactor of a cause or undertaking

dt: {bc}a small, primarily nocturnal, arboreal, marsupial {d_link|possum|possum} ({it}Petaurus breviceps{/it} of the family Petauridae) of Australia, New Guinea, and the Moluccas that has soft, silvery gray to brown fur and a bushy often white-tipped tail, that typically feeds on sap, nectar, and insects, and that is sometimes kept as a pet
The sugar glider has a fold of skin extending from the front to rear foot enabling it to make long, gliding leaps.

dt.t: But while all these saps and juices are a good source of energy-rich sugars, they need to be supplemented by protein, especially at breeding time. So in spring and early summer, the {wi}sugar gliders{/wi} switch their attention to insects.
{wi}Sugar gliders{/wi} can make good pets. … They are naturally inquisitive and will chew and swallow many things, so it is not recommended to provide toys.

shortdef: a small, primarily nocturnal, arboreal, marsupial possum (Petaurus breviceps of the family Petauridae) of Australia, New Guinea, and the Moluccas that has soft, silvery gray to brown fur and a bushy often white-tipped tail, that typically feeds on sap, nectar, and insects, and that is sometimes kept as a pet

dt: {bc}a maple ({it}Acer saccharum{/it}) of eastern North America with 3- to 5-lobed leaves, hard close-grained wood much used for cabinetwork, and sap that is the chief source of maple syrup and maple sugar
{bc}any of several maples (especially {it}Acer nigrum{/it} and {it}A. grandidentatum{/it}) often considered subspecies of the sugar maple

shortdef: a maple (Acer saccharum) of eastern North America with 3- to 5-lobed leaves, hard close-grained wood much used for cabinetwork, and sap that is the chief source of maple syrup and maple sugar —called also rock maple, hard maple
any of several maples (especially Acer nigrum and A. grandidentatum) often considered subspecies of the sugar maple

dt: {bc}to complete the process of boiling down the syrup in making maple sugar until it is thick enough to crystallize
{bc}to approach or reach the state of granulation

shortdef: to complete the process of boiling down the syrup in making maple sugar until it is thick enough to crystallize
to approach or reach the state of granulation
